facts.text: Dr. S. Dutt examined as expert witness by defence in Sessions trial State v. Matadin and Ors., S.T. No. 60 of 1957, before Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi.
Dr. Dutt claimed diploma from Imperial College of Science and Technology, London, specializing in criminology.
Cross-examined by District Government Counsel assisted by Mr. Shyam Narain, Deputy Superintendent, Police C.I.D. Lucknow, who had deposed as prosecution expert.
Dr. Dutt's testimony ran counter to Mr. Shyam Narain's; credentials challenged.
Judge asked Dr. Dutt to produce academic diplomas and certificates; produced diploma (Ex. P-71) and statement (Ex. P-72).
Sessions Judge acquitted Matadin and others on October 29, 1957; passed strictures on prosecution; did not accept Shyam Narain's evidence.
Government did not appeal against acquittal.
On November 12, 1957, prosecution applied to Sessions Judge under s.195 CrPC for prosecution of Dr. Dutt under s.193 IPC for forgery of diploma and using as genuine; application rejected same day.

On November 14, 1957, Mr. Shyam Narain lodged report at Police Station, Hardoi, alleging offence under s.466/477 IPC (subsequently changed to s.465/471 IPC) for forging and using forged diploma in court.
On October 26, 1958, charge-sheet under s.465/471 IPC filed against Dr. Dutt by C.I.D. Police, Lucknow, in Court of Judicial Officer III, Hardoi.
Case transferred to Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Hardoi.

At commencement of trial, Dr. Dutt objected that prosecution barred without court complaint under s.195 CrPC as offence under s.193 IPC; contended ss.465/471 do not apply; also s.196 applies requiring s.195.
Prosecution contended offence under ss.465/471 for forgery and using forged document.
Additional District Magistrate rejected contentions; held no bar to trial under ss.465/471 IPC.
Dr. Dutt filed revisions in Sessions Court and Allahabad High Court; both failed.
Allahabad High Court (Lucknow Bench, Mr. Justice Misra) order dated February 12, 1965, dismissing revision.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court: Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1965.

legal_issues.text: Whether the alleged offence falls under ss.465/471 IPC (forgery and using forged document as genuine) allowing prosecution without court complaint under s.195 CrPC, or under ss.193/196 IPC (false evidence/fabricating/using false evidence) requiring court complaint under s.195 CrPC.
Whether prosecution evaded s.195 CrPC by charging under ss.465/471 instead of ss.193/196.

petitioner_arguments.text: Offence, if any, under s.193 or 196 IPC, not ss.465/471; requires complaint under s.195 CrPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 193, 196 IPC; s.195 CrPC; Basir-ul-Huq v. State of West Bengal

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution attempting to evade s.195 CrPC; ss.465/471 do not apply; s.196 applies.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.195 CrPC; Basir-ul-Huq observations against evasion

respondent_arguments.text: Dr. Dutt prosecuted for forgery of diploma and using forged document as genuine under ss.465/471 IPC; no requirement for court complaint as not committed by party.

court_reasoning.text: s.195 CrPC bars cognizance without court complaint for offences under ss.193-196,199,200 IPC; for forgery under s.463 or using under s.471 etc. in evidence by non-party, no complaint needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction: ss.193/196 cover false evidence in judicial proceedings; ss.465/471 general forgery.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Dutt's act covered by s.192 (fabricating false evidence) as made document with false statement intending it appear in evidence to cause erroneous opinion on material point.
court_reasoning.key_observation: As expert witness, diploma supported claim material to trial.

court_reasoning.text: Use of diploma as genuine was corrupt under s.196 (wider than fraudulent/dishonest); offence under s.193 if gave false evidence.

No offence under s.465/471: No making false document by Dr. Dutt per s.464; use not dishonest (no wrongful gain/loss per s.24); not fraudulent (no intent to defraud causing disadvantageous action per s.25).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Produced under court order, not voluntarily; intent to deceive but not defraud.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution chose lesser offence to bypass s.195; Sessions Judge already rejected s.193 prosecution; evasion not permitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.196 more serious (7 years) than ss.465/471 (2 years).

holdings.text: Offence falls under ss.192/193/196 IPC, requires court complaint under s.195 CrPC; does not fall under ss.465/471 IPC.
Prosecution launched without required complaint is invalid; cannot evade s.195 by misdescribing offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basir-ul-Huq v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: s.195 cannot be evaded by devices or camouflages; test is whether facts disclose primarily offence requiring complaint.
Corruptly wider than fraudulently or dishonestly.
Corruptly much wider than dishonestly or fraudulently; includes blameworthy or improper conduct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ramaswami
precedents_cited.relevance: Producing document on court order not use under s.471 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ma Ain Lon v. Ma On Nu
precedents_cited.relevance: Producing document on court order not use under s.471 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction: deceive induces belief; defraud induces action to disadvantage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Welham v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents_cited.relevance: Intent to defraud need not cause economic loss.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars cognizance of offences against public justice (ss.193-196 etc. IPC) and certain forgeries in court without written court complaint.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines forgery, false evidence, fabricating/using false evidence, dishonest/fraudulent intent; court held acts fall under false evidence provisions, not general forgery.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court order, and held that the prosecution under ss.465/471 IPC cannot proceed as the offence falls under ss.193/196 IPC requiring complaint under s.195 CrPC, which was not obtained.

key_quotes.text: "Though, in our judgment, section 195 does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same facts and which is not included within the ambit of that section, it has also to be borne in mind that the provisions of that section cannot be evaded by resorting to devices or camouflages."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cited from Basir-ul-Huq; central to holding against evasion of s.195 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: "The gist of the provision is that offences of forgery of a document as described in s.463 P.C. and of using such forged documents, if produced or given in evidence by a person other than a party to a proceeding in a court, do not require a complaint in writing of the court concerned."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion, the offence in the present case did not fall within ss.465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on."
key_quotes.speaker: court
